elements.content: A study of the single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation induced by temperature variation for the chain polymer Cu­(II) complex with nitronyl nitroxide showed that an increase in the hydrostatic pressure of up to ∼0.07 GPa completely changes the intracrystalline displacements of molecules relative to one another. This, in turn, significantly affects the interaction energy of the unpaired electrons of the paramagnetic centers and hence the form of the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility χT. The cooling of crystals under normal conditions causes a rearrangement of the intrachain exchange clusters {>N–•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N<} accompanied by a shortening of the distances between the paramagnetic centers. This changes the character of exchange interactions and generates multistage spin transitions. An increase in the hydrostatic pressure leads to a drastic change in the O···O distances between the nitroxyl fragments of adjacent chains, an increase in the antiferromagnetic exchange between them, and complete suppression of spin transitions.
elements.clean_text: A study of the single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation induced by temperature variation for the chain polymer Cu(II) complex with nitronyl nitroxide showed that an increase in the hydrostatic pressure of up to ~0.07 GPa completely changes the intracrystalline displacements of molecules relative to one another. This, in turn, significantly affects the interaction energy of the unpaired electrons of the paramagnetic centers and hence the form of the temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility χT. The cooling of crystals under normal conditions causes a rearrangement of the intrachain exchange clusters {>N-⋅O-Cu(II)-O⋅-N<} accompanied by a shortening of the distances between the paramagnetic centers. This changes the character of exchange interactions and generates multistage spin transitions. An increase in the hydrostatic pressure leads to a drastic change in the O⋅⋅⋅O distances between the nitroxyl fragments of adjacent chains, an increase in the antiferromagnetic exchange between them, and complete suppression of spin transitions.

elements.content: A study of the single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation induced by temperature variation for the chain polymer Cu­(II) complex with nitronyl nitroxide showed that an increase in the hydrostatic pressure of up to ∼0.07 GPa leads to a drastic change in the O···O distances between the nitroxyl fragments of adjacent chains, an increase in the antiferromagnetic exchange between them, and complete suppression of spin transitions in the >N−•O−Cu­(II)−O•−N< exchange clusters.
elements.clean_text: A study of the single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation induced by temperature variation for the chain polymer Cu(II) complex with nitronyl nitroxide showed that an increase in the hydrostatic pressure of up to ~0.07 GPa leads to a drastic change in the O⋅⋅⋅O distances between the nitroxyl fragments of adjacent chains, an increase in the antiferromagnetic exchange between them, and complete suppression of spin transitions in the >N-⋅O-Cu(II)-O⋅-N< exchange clusters.

elements.content: A study of the properties of molecular magnets is the subject of active interdisciplinary fundamental research in view of the high potential of their application in various fields of biology and medicine and creation of a new generation of functional materials and spintronic devices. A wide range of molecular magnets are known in which the structure and functional properties can change under the influence of external factors, for example, irradiation or variation of temperature, pressure, or electromagnetic field, or during redox processes. The effect of the external pressure remains least understood. The data of studies that compared the polymorphic transformations induced by temperature variation at different external pressures are especially scarce, though they provide important information about the fundamental properties of objects and serve as a basis for creating energy-independent highly sensitive pressure sensors for space and seismological studies and original devices capable of light emission at increased pressure or work at low temperatures under conditions of underground and deep-sea exploration.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

A study of the properties of molecular magnets is the subject of active interdisciplinary fundamental research in view of the high potential of their application in various fields of biology and medicine and creation of a new generation of functional materials and spintronic devices. A wide range of molecular magnets are known in which the structure and functional properties can change under the influence of external factors, for example, irradiation or variation of temperature, pressure, or electromagnetic field, or during redox processes. The effect of the external pressure remains least understood. The data of studies that compared the polymorphic transformations induced by temperature variation at different external pressures are especially scarce, though they provide important information about the fundamental properties of objects and serve as a basis for creating energy-independent highly sensitive pressure sensors for space and seismological studies and original devices capable of light emission at increased pressure or work at low temperatures under conditions of underground and deep-sea exploration.

elements.content: Heterospin compounds based on Cu­(II) complexes with nitroxides, exhibiting effects similar to spin crossover (SCO), belong to interesting compounds for investigating the temperature-induced phase transformations at different pressures. A rearrangement of the two ({Cu­(II)–O•–N< }) or three-({>N–•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N< }) spin heterospin exchange clusters occurs during the temperature-induced structural phase transition, leading to a change in the energy of exchange interaction between the unpaired electrons of the paramagnetic centers. This results in anomalies on the temperature dependence of the χT similar to spin transitions and is often accompanied by a significant change in the color of the compound. It should be noted that despite the significant structure rearrangements, the phase transitions can occur without decomposition of single crystals, which is especially important for correlating the structural changes with magnetic properties for this group of compounds. In contrast to the actively studied pressure effect on the structure and magnetic properties of iron, cobalt, and manganese complexes, exhibiting spin transitions and valence tautomerism, the pressure effect on the magnetic properties of 3d metal complexes with nitroxides was studied only for a few bulk magnetic-ordered 1D complexes of Mn and Cu­(II) coordination compounds exhibiting effects similar to SCO. An increase in pressure completely suppressed the magnetic anomaly for the Cu­(hfac)2 complex with dinitroxide, and provoked an increase in the transition temperature for Cu­(II) complexes with pyrazolyl-substituted nitronyl nitroxides. The study of changes in the structure of the compound when the pressure changes was not carried out in any of the above cases.
elements.clean_text: Heterospin compounds based on Cu(II) complexes with nitroxides, exhibiting effects similar to spin crossover (SCO), belong to interesting compounds for investigating the temperature-induced phase transformations at different pressures. A rearrangement of the two ({Cu(II)-O⋅-N< }) or three-({>N-⋅O-Cu(II)-O⋅-N< }) spin heterospin exchange clusters occurs during the temperature-induced structural phase transition, leading to a change in the energy of exchange interaction between the unpaired electrons of the paramagnetic centers. This results in anomalies on the temperature dependence of the χT similar to spin transitions and is often accompanied by a significant change in the color of the compound. It should be noted that despite the significant structure rearrangements, the phase transitions can occur without decomposition of single crystals, which is especially important for correlating the structural changes with magnetic properties for this group of compounds. In contrast to the actively studied pressure effect on the structure and magnetic properties of iron, cobalt, and manganese complexes, exhibiting spin transitions and valence tautomerism, the pressure effect on the magnetic properties of 3d metal complexes with nitroxides was studied only for a few bulk magnetic-ordered 1D complexes of Mn and Cu(II) coordination compounds exhibiting effects similar to SCO. An increase in pressure completely suppressed the magnetic anomaly for the Cu(hfac)2 complex with dinitroxide, and provoked an increase in the transition temperature for Cu(II) complexes with pyrazolyl-substituted nitronyl nitroxides. The study of changes in the structure of the compound when the pressure changes was not carried out in any of the above cases.

elements.content: We performed these experiments for crystals of the Cu­(II) chain-polymer complex with 4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-2-(1-methyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)-imidazoline-3-oxide-1-oxyl (L) with a head-to-tail chain motif [Cu­(hfac)2L]-I (), for which the temperature induced structural transformation and the thermocompression dependence of magnetic properties had been studied before. However, the [Cu­(hfac)2L]-I crystals were destroyed even at a slightly increased pressure (P ∼0.07 GPa), which hindered the study of the structure transformation under these conditions. As the compound can be obtained in the form of different polymorphs depending on the synthesis conditions, for further study we chose the modification [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II with a head-to-head chain motif (). For [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II, the temperature dependence of χT is much smoother. Therefore, it was assumed that the modification had high mechanical elasticity, which favored a detailed study of structure transformations induced by a decrease in temperature at different pressures.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

We performed these experiments for crystals of the Cu(II) chain-polymer complex with 4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-2-(1-methyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)-imidazoline-3-oxide-1-oxyl (L) with a head-to-tail chain motif [Cu(hfac)2L]-I (), for which the temperature induced structural transformation and the thermocompression dependence of magnetic properties had been studied before. However, the [Cu(hfac)2L]-I crystals were destroyed even at a slightly increased pressure (P ~0.07 GPa), which hindered the study of the structure transformation under these conditions. As the compound can be obtained in the form of different polymorphs depending on the synthesis conditions, for further study we chose the modification [Cu(hfac)2L]-II with a head-to-head chain motif (). For [Cu(hfac)2L]-II, the temperature dependence of χT is much smoother. Therefore, it was assumed that the modification had high mechanical elasticity, which favored a detailed study of structure transformations induced by a decrease in temperature at different pressures.

elements.content: Chains in the structure of [Cu­(hfac)2L]-I (a) and [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II (b) and dependences χT(T) at P = 1 atm (red) and 0.07 GPa (purple) for [Cu­(hfac)2L]-I (c) and [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II (d). The H atoms and the geminal CH3 and CF3 groups are omitted.
elements.clean_text: 1  Chains in the structure of [Cu(hfac)2L]-I (a) and [Cu(hfac)2L]-II (b) and dependences χT(T) at P = 1 atm (red) and 0.07 GPa (purple) for [Cu(hfac)2L]-I (c) and [Cu(hfac)2L]-II (d). The H atoms and the geminal CH3 and CF3 groups are omitted.

elements.content: Experiments revealed unique changes in the magnetic properties of [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II at increased hydrostatic pressure. For [Cu­(hfac)2L]-I, the spin transition temperature increased (c) and the general character of χT(T) remained the same, whereas for [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II, even a slight increase in pressure completely altered the form of χT(T) (d). This response of magnetic properties to a small increase in external pressure had never been encountered for transition metal compounds with organic ligands exhibiting spin transition effects and predetermined interest in studies of the [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II structure at increased external pressure. However, before considering the effect of pressure in more detail, it is instructive to address structural behavior of this compound at variable temperatures.
elements.clean_text: Experiments revealed unique changes in the magnetic properties of [Cu(hfac)2L]-II at increased hydrostatic pressure. For [Cu(hfac)2L]-I, the spin transition temperature increased (c) and the general character of χT(T) remained the same, whereas for [Cu(hfac)2L]-II, even a slight increase in pressure completely altered the form of χT(T) (d). This response of magnetic properties to a small increase in external pressure had never been encountered for transition metal compounds with organic ligands exhibiting spin transition effects and predetermined interest in studies of the [Cu(hfac)2L]-II structure at increased external pressure. However, before considering the effect of pressure in more detail, it is instructive to address structural behavior of this compound at variable temperatures.

elements.content: The most important characteristics of the structure of [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II under the normal conditions are the relatively short Cu–ONO distances (2.336(1) Å) in the {CuO6} units and the long Cu–N distances (2.557(2) Å) in the CuO4N2 units. When the temperature is lowered to 30 K, the Cu–ONO distances are shortened stepwise by 0.336 Å (Table S1). The Cu–O bonds on one of the Ohfac–Cu–Ohfac axes are lengthened by a comparable value (0.337 Å). Thus, the long axis of the Cu bipyramid in the CuO6 square bipyramid actually changes: the coordinated O atoms of the nitroxyl group pass to the equatorial position, displacing two Ohfac atoms to the axial positions. In the {CuO4N2} units, the Cu–N axial distances are shortened to a lesser extent (by 0.100 Å), while the N–Cu–N axis remains elongated. The O···O interchain contacts between the noncoordinated NO groups of the paramagnetic ligands decrease from 3.901 Å at 295 K to 3.571 Å at 30 K. These data completely correlate with the data of Q- and W-band CW EPR measurements, which unambiguously confirm that the Jahn–Teller axis in the {CuO6} units (>N–•O–Cu–O•–N<) has flipped (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text: The most important characteristics of the structure of [Cu(hfac)2L]-II under the normal conditions are the relatively short Cu-ONO distances (2.336(1) Å) in the {CuO6} units and the long Cu-N distances (2.557(2) Å) in the CuO4N2 units. When the temperature is lowered to 30 K, the Cu-ONO distances are shortened stepwise by 0.336 Å (Table S1). The Cu-O bonds on one of the Ohfac-Cu-Ohfac axes are lengthened by a comparable value (0.337 Å). Thus, the long axis of the Cu bipyramid in the CuO6 square bipyramid actually changes: the coordinated O atoms of the nitroxyl group pass to the equatorial position, displacing two Ohfac atoms to the axial positions. In the {CuO4N2} units, the Cu-N axial distances are shortened to a lesser extent (by 0.100 Å), while the N-Cu-N axis remains elongated. The O⋅⋅⋅O interchain contacts between the noncoordinated NO groups of the paramagnetic ligands decrease from 3.901 Å at 295 K to 3.571 Å at 30 K. These data completely correlate with the data of Q- and W-band CW EPR measurements, which unambiguously confirm that the Jahn-Teller axis in the {CuO6} units (>N-⋅O-Cu-O⋅-N<) has flipped (Figure S2).

elements.content: The shortening of the Cu–ONO bond lengths in the > N–•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N< exchange clusters observed during the cooling of the crystal is the cause of the increase in the fraction of the low-temperature phase with strong antiferromagnetic exchange interactions in the {>N–•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N<} exchange clusters in the high-temperature phase, which is reflected by the decreased χT value ().
elements.clean_text: The shortening of the Cu-ONO bond lengths in the > N-⋅O-Cu(II)-O⋅-N< exchange clusters observed during the cooling of the crystal is the cause of the increase in the fraction of the low-temperature phase with strong antiferromagnetic exchange interactions in the {>N-⋅O-Cu(II)-O⋅-N<} exchange clusters in the high-temperature phase, which is reflected by the decreased χT value ().

elements.content: It is noteworthy that there is discontinuity in the structural data for 0.07 to 0.26 GPa. d shows that an insignificant increase in pressure almost completely terminates the migration (i.e., significant displacement) of atoms inside the {>N–•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N<} exchange clusters, due to which the steps of spin transitions vanish in the low-temperature range. Analyzing the obtained set of structural data, we found that after an insignificant increase in pressure (Figures S1a, b), the CF3 group of one of the hfac anions ceased to rotate (Figure S1a shows its disordering) because it approached the radical molecule inside the chain. This hinders the migration of the radical molecule to the copper ion at least up to the applied external pressure of ∼0.14 GPa (Figure S1d). When the pressure increases further to 0.23 GPa and higher (Figures S1e , f), the CF3 group moves away from the radical molecule, making it possible for atoms to come closer inside the {>N–•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N<} exchange clusters in the polymer chain. As a result, at higher pressures in the range 4–50 K, the curves become similar to the curve observed at decreased temperatures under the normal conditions.
elements.clean_text: It is noteworthy that there is discontinuity in the structural data for 0.07 to 0.26 GPa. d shows that an insignificant increase in pressure almost completely terminates the migration (i.e., significant displacement) of atoms inside the {>N-⋅O-Cu(II)-O⋅-N<} exchange clusters, due to which the steps of spin transitions vanish in the low-temperature range. Analyzing the obtained set of structural data, we found that after an insignificant increase in pressure (Figures S1a, b), the CF3 group of one of the hfac anions ceased to rotate (Figure S1a shows its disordering) because it approached the radical molecule inside the chain. This hinders the migration of the radical molecule to the copper ion at least up to the applied external pressure of ~0.14 GPa (Figure S1d). When the pressure increases further to 0.23 GPa and higher (Figures S1e , f), the CF3 group moves away from the radical molecule, making it possible for atoms to come closer inside the {>N-⋅O-Cu(II)-O⋅-N<} exchange clusters in the polymer chain. As a result, at higher pressures in the range 4-50 K, the curves become similar to the curve observed at decreased temperatures under the normal conditions.

elements.content: A study of the crystal structure of [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II due to pressure variation revealed non monotonous variation of the unit cell parameters. When the pressure increases to 0.23 GPa, the a parameter decreases by more than 1 Å; the c parameter at first increases and then decreases as the pressure increases further (). This variation in parameters differs widely from their course of change in the case of the temperature lowered at normal pressure (), when the a and c parameters significantly decrease and the b parameter remains almost constant. The decrease in the unit cell volume is more than 7% at a pressure increased to 0.23 GPa (Figure S3) and 12.6% over the whole range of pressure variation (0.0001–0.75 GPa), which is considerably larger than at normal pressure (∼8.7% in the temperature range 30–295 K). These differences in the consequence of the voids reducing in the [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II structure are shown in Figure S4. It is especially important that the O···O interchain distances between the noncoordinated NO groups are also shortened by a very large value of 0.878 Å (0.709 Å in the range 0.01–0.23 GPa and then by another 0.169 Å in the range 0.23–0.75 GPa) ( and Figure S4).
elements.clean_text: A study of the crystal structure of [Cu(hfac)2L]-II due to pressure variation revealed non monotonous variation of the unit cell parameters. When the pressure increases to 0.23 GPa, the a parameter decreases by more than 1 Å; the c parameter at first increases and then decreases as the pressure increases further (). This variation in parameters differs widely from their course of change in the case of the temperature lowered at normal pressure (), when the a and c parameters significantly decrease and the b parameter remains almost constant. The decrease in the unit cell volume is more than 7% at a pressure increased to 0.23 GPa (Figure S3) and 12.6% over the whole range of pressure variation (0.0001-0.75 GPa), which is considerably larger than at normal pressure (~8.7% in the temperature range 30-295 K). These differences in the consequence of the voids reducing in the [Cu(hfac)2L]-II structure are shown in Figure S4. It is especially important that the O⋅⋅⋅O interchain distances between the noncoordinated NO groups are also shortened by a very large value of 0.878 Å (0.709 Å in the range 0.01-0.23 GPa and then by another 0.169 Å in the range 0.23-0.75 GPa) ( and Figure S4).

elements.content: Variation of the unit-cell parameters (a) with pressure at room temperature and (b) with temperature at atmospheric pressure.
elements.clean_text: 2  Variation of the unit-cell parameters (a) with pressure at room temperature and (b) with temperature at atmospheric pressure.

elements.content: Variation in the Cu–ONO (squares), Cu–N (circles), and interchain ONO···ONO (triangles) distances due to the temperature variation at normal (red) and elevated (purple) pressure in [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II.
elements.clean_text: 3  Variation in the Cu-ONO (squares), Cu-N (circles), and interchain ONO⋅⋅⋅ONO (triangles) distances due to the temperature variation at normal (red) and elevated (purple) pressure in [Cu(hfac)2L]-II.

elements.content: The χT value of [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II (, red circles) at 300 K and atmospheric pressure is 0.89 cm3·K·mol–1, which agrees with the theoretical pure spin value of 0.81 cm3 K mol–1 for two noninteracting spins with S = 1/2 (g R = 2.00, g Cu = 2.15). During the cooling, χT decreases stepwise at ∼140, ∼75, and ∼60 K to the value of 0.40 cm3 K mol–1 characteristic of systems with one unpaired electron for the indicated composition.
elements.clean_text: The χT value of [Cu(hfac)2L]-II (, red circles) at 300 K and atmospheric pressure is 0.89 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, which agrees with the theoretical pure spin value of 0.81 cm3 K mol-1 for two noninteracting spins with S = 1/2 (g R = 2.00, g Cu = 2.15). During the cooling, χT decreases stepwise at ~140, ~75, and ~60 K to the value of 0.40 cm3 K mol-1 characteristic of systems with one unpaired electron for the indicated composition.

elements.content: Experimental dependences χT(T) for the polycrystalline [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II samples at different pressures.
elements.clean_text: 4  Experimental dependences χT(T) for the polycrystalline [Cu(hfac)2L]-II samples at different pressures.

elements.content: An increase in the hydrostatic pressure to 0.07 GPa (, violet diamonds) leads to an unprecedented change in the magnetic properties of the complex: χT decreases to 0.83 cm3·K·mol–1 and remains almost constant in the temperature range 25–300 K; i.e., this relatively small increase in pressure suppresses the three-stage magnetic anomaly observed at atmospheric pressure. When the pressure increases further from 0.07 to 0.78 GPa, χT decreases from 0.83 to 0.51 cm3 K mol–1 already at 300 K, and the dependences χT(T) show a smooth decrease in χT at lower temperatures, reaching ∼0.38 cm3 K mol–1 at T ≈ 100 K, which corresponds to one unpaired electron (S = 1/2).
elements.clean_text: An increase in the hydrostatic pressure to 0.07 GPa (, violet diamonds) leads to an unprecedented change in the magnetic properties of the complex: χT decreases to 0.83 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 and remains almost constant in the temperature range 25-300 K; i.e., this relatively small increase in pressure suppresses the three-stage magnetic anomaly observed at atmospheric pressure. When the pressure increases further from 0.07 to 0.78 GPa, χT decreases from 0.83 to 0.51 cm3 K mol-1 already at 300 K, and the dependences χT(T) show a smooth decrease in χT at lower temperatures, reaching ~0.38 cm3 K mol-1 at T ~ 100 K, which corresponds to one unpaired electron (S = 1/2).

elements.content: Thus, the lowered temperature and elevated pressure ultimately lead to a strengthening of antiferromagnetic exchange interactions in solid [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II and to a change in the orientation of the Jahn–Teller axis in the CuO6 coordination units, which are three-spin exchange clusters {>N–•O–CuII–O•–N<}, from ONO–Cu–ONO to Ohfac–Cu–Ohfac. However, these processes occur differently, as indicated by the XRD data (Tables S1 and S2 and ) and the change in the character of the χT(T) dependence.
elements.clean_text: Thus, the lowered temperature and elevated pressure ultimately lead to a strengthening of antiferromagnetic exchange interactions in solid [Cu(hfac)2L]-II and to a change in the orientation of the Jahn-Teller axis in the CuO6 coordination units, which are three-spin exchange clusters {>N-⋅O-CuII-O⋅-N<}, from ONO-Cu-ONO to Ohfac-Cu-Ohfac. However, these processes occur differently, as indicated by the XRD data (Tables S1 and S2 and ) and the change in the character of the χT(T) dependence.

elements.content: The results of quantum-chemical modeling of exchange interactions using the molecular (ORCA 3.0 and Gaussian 09) and band structure (Quantum Espresso 5.0) approaches (Tables S3 and S4), agree with the experimental data in the case of the “static” approach, in which the crystal structure is regarded as a solid solution of high- and low-temperature phases, and the Cu–ONO distances agree with the average values of distances in the high- (HS) and low-spin (LS) exchange clusters with a fraction ω. When calculating ω, as reference values (for ω = 1 and ω = 0) we took the Cu–O bond lengths in exchange clusters at atmospheric pressure (T = 295 and 30 K), i.e., when the maximum number of weakly (ω = 0) and strongly (ω = 1) bonded triads, respectively, were accumulated in the solid under experimental conditions. The suppression of spin transitions in exchange clusters at P < 0.07 GPa is due to the fact that the temperature transition HS → LS for exchange clusters (see the Supporting Information) is sterically difficult at low pressures, which is associated with a specific deformation of the polymer chains.
elements.clean_text: The results of quantum-chemical modeling of exchange interactions using the molecular (ORCA 3.0 and Gaussian 09) and band structure (Quantum Espresso 5.0) approaches (Tables S3 and S4), agree with the experimental data in the case of the "static" approach, in which the crystal structure is regarded as a solid solution of high- and low-temperature phases, and the Cu-ONO distances agree with the average values of distances in the high- (HS) and low-spin (LS) exchange clusters with a fraction ω. When calculating ω, as reference values (for ω = 1 and ω = 0) we took the Cu-O bond lengths in exchange clusters at atmospheric pressure (T = 295 and 30 K), i.e., when the maximum number of weakly (ω = 0) and strongly (ω = 1) bonded triads, respectively, were accumulated in the solid under experimental conditions. The suppression of spin transitions in exchange clusters at P < 0.07 GPa is due to the fact that the temperature transition HS → LS for exchange clusters (see the Supporting Information) is sterically difficult at low pressures, which is associated with a specific deformation of the polymer chains.

elements.content: The calculations showed that the interchain exchange between nitroxides (Tables S3 and S4) is significant for this system. “Magnetic chains” of three-spin exchange clusters, which differ from the structural chains in direction, and magnetically isolated layers of single-spin coordination centers can be isolated in crystal. The negative values of exchange integrals of intercluster interactions obtained in calculations agree well with the decreased χT at temperatures below 30 K. Nevertheless, their inclusion in calculation only slightly affected the obtained χT values and did not qualitatively change the behavior of the calculated χT(T) and χT(P) dependences ( and ).
elements.clean_text: The calculations showed that the interchain exchange between nitroxides (Tables S3 and S4) is significant for this system. "Magnetic chains" of three-spin exchange clusters, which differ from the structural chains in direction, and magnetically isolated layers of single-spin coordination centers can be isolated in crystal. The negative values of exchange integrals of intercluster interactions obtained in calculations agree well with the decreased χT at temperatures below 30 K. Nevertheless, their inclusion in calculation only slightly affected the obtained χT values and did not qualitatively change the behavior of the calculated χT(T) and χT(P) dependences ( and ).

elements.content: Experimental (black circles and line) and calculated χT(T) dependences for [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II. The theoretical points were obtained using the magnetic coupling constants calculated by DFT with neglect of the interchain magnetic coupling J O···O (Table S3): UB3LYP/TZVP (blue squares and dashed line), GGA+U (red triangles).
elements.clean_text: 5  Experimental (black circles and line) and calculated χT(T) dependences for [Cu(hfac)2L]-II. The theoretical points were obtained using the magnetic coupling constants calculated by DFT with neglect of the interchain magnetic coupling J O⋅⋅⋅O (Table S3): UB3LYP/TZVP (blue squares and dashed line), GGA+U (red triangles).

elements.content: Experimental (black circles and line) and calculated χT(P) dependences for [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II. The theoretical points were obtained using the magnetic coupling constants calculated by DFT with neglect of the interchain magnetic coupling J O···O (Table S4): UB3LYP/TZVP (blue squares and dashed line), GGA+U (red triangles).
elements.clean_text: 6  Experimental (black circles and line) and calculated χT(P) dependences for [Cu(hfac)2L]-II. The theoretical points were obtained using the magnetic coupling constants calculated by DFT with neglect of the interchain magnetic coupling J O⋅⋅⋅O (Table S4): UB3LYP/TZVP (blue squares and dashed line), GGA+U (red triangles).

elements.content: The calculated temperature dependence χT(T) at atmospheric pressure is presented in . The quality of approximation of experimental data within the framework of the static model is roughly the same for all the methods used for calculating the exchange integrals presented in Table S3. The same is observed for the experiment on pressure at T = 295 K (). The observed discrepancy between the experimental and calculated χT(P) dependences is explained by the difference in the temperature conditions of pressure evaluation: at room temperature in the XRD study and at low temperatures (6.8–7.2 K) in the magnetic measurements. An increase in the internal pressure of the solidified and/or liquid oil during its heating from 6 to 300 K may be 0.15–0.20 GPa, which agrees fairly well with the shift of the χT values obtained in magnetochemical experiments along the P axis compared with the values calculated from the XRD data.
elements.clean_text: The calculated temperature dependence χT(T) at atmospheric pressure is presented in . The quality of approximation of experimental data within the framework of the static model is roughly the same for all the methods used for calculating the exchange integrals presented in Table S3. The same is observed for the experiment on pressure at T = 295 K (). The observed discrepancy between the experimental and calculated χT(P) dependences is explained by the difference in the temperature conditions of pressure evaluation: at room temperature in the XRD study and at low temperatures (6.8-7.2 K) in the magnetic measurements. An increase in the internal pressure of the solidified and/or liquid oil during its heating from 6 to 300 K may be 0.15-0.20 GPa, which agrees fairly well with the shift of the χT values obtained in magnetochemical experiments along the P axis compared with the values calculated from the XRD data.

elements.content: Thus, the study revealed a substantial difference between the temperature-induced structural transformations at atmospheric pressure and elevated hydrostatic pressure. For the [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II heterospin complex, it was found that a reasonably small increase in the hydrostatic pressure can completely change the character of magnetic effects on the curve of the χT(T) dependence. This indicates that heterospin complexes of this type can perform the function of a sensor that is highly sensitive to the variation of the external pressure.
elements.clean_text: Thus, the study revealed a substantial difference between the temperature-induced structural transformations at atmospheric pressure and elevated hydrostatic pressure. For the [Cu(hfac)2L]-II heterospin complex, it was found that a reasonably small increase in the hydrostatic pressure can completely change the character of magnetic effects on the curve of the χT(T) dependence. This indicates that heterospin complexes of this type can perform the function of a sensor that is highly sensitive to the variation of the external pressure.

elements.content: To summarize, it has not yet been studied why this anomalous response to the imposed external pressure is inherent in [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II nature; this will be the subject of further studies. One can suggest that the spin coupling is favorable for substantial migration of molecules in space: as a result of the approach of atoms in the {>N-•O–Cu­(II)–O•–N<} or {−•O···O•−} exchange clusters, the antiferromagnetic exchange energy between the unpaired electrons of the paramagnetic centers drastically increases. The antiferromagnetic exchange is some kind of analog of a chemical bond; therefore, its growth leads to a strengthening of the interatomic bond. If the nitroxide in its complex with the paramagnetic metal is replaced by its diamagnetic structural analog, the exchange clusters with pronounced interaction energy disappear. As a consequence, the substantial migrations of molecules relative to one another vanish in the solid compound.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

To summarize, it has not yet been studied why this anomalous response to the imposed external pressure is inherent in [Cu(hfac)2L]-II nature; this will be the subject of further studies. One can suggest that the spin coupling is favorable for substantial migration of molecules in space: as a result of the approach of atoms in the {>N-⋅O-Cu(II)-O⋅-N<} or {-⋅O⋅⋅⋅O⋅-} exchange clusters, the antiferromagnetic exchange energy between the unpaired electrons of the paramagnetic centers drastically increases. The antiferromagnetic exchange is some kind of analog of a chemical bond; therefore, its growth leads to a strengthening of the interatomic bond. If the nitroxide in its complex with the paramagnetic metal is replaced by its diamagnetic structural analog, the exchange clusters with pronounced interaction energy disappear. As a consequence, the substantial migrations of molecules relative to one another vanish in the solid compound.

elements.content: The X-ray diffraction experiments were performed on a SMART APEX II automated diffractometer (Bruker AXS) with a Helix low-temperature accessory (Oxford Cryosystem). The low-temperature experiments were performed by the standard procedure using a high-pressure cell with diamond anvils; the transmitting medium was fluorinated silicon oil; the pressure was monitored according to the displacement of the fluorescence line of ruby.The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares in an anisotropic approximation for all non-hydrogen atoms. The H atoms were located geometrically and refined in a riding model. All calculations on structure solution and refinement were performed with SHELXL-2016/6 software.The crystal data for the compounds and the details of experiments are given in Table S5.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

The X-ray diffraction experiments were performed on a SMART APEX II automated diffractometer (Bruker AXS) with a Helix low-temperature accessory (Oxford Cryosystem). The low-temperature experiments were performed by the standard procedure using a high-pressure cell with diamond anvils; the transmitting medium was fluorinated silicon oil; the pressure was monitored according to the displacement of the fluorescence line of ruby.The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares in an anisotropic approximation for all non-hydrogen atoms. The H atoms were located geometrically and refined in a riding model. All calculations on structure solution and refinement were performed with SHELXL-2016/6 software.The crystal data for the compounds and the details of experiments are given in Table S5.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed using an MPMS-2 SQUID magnetometer in the temperature range 6–300 K in a magnetic field of 5 kOe. The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility at pressures of 1.0 × 10–4 ⩽ P ⩽ 0.48 GPa was measured in an LPC-15 high-pressure copper–beryllium cell of cylinder-piston type (Japan ElectroLAB) using Daphne 7373 oil as a medium transmitting the hydrostatic pressure, as described elsewhere. The magnetic susceptibility measurements at atmospheric pressure (1.0 × 10–4 GPa) and at a pressure of 0.07–0.78 GPa were performed while cooling/heating the [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II samples at a rate of 1 K/min in the temperature range of the magnetic anomaly (ca. T a ± (20–30) K) and at 5 K/min in the other temperature range (settle mode). The experimental data were corrected for the contribution of the high-pressure cell to the total magnetization. In the molar susceptibility calculation, the diamagnetism of atoms was additionally taken into account according to Pascal’s additive scheme. The critical temperatures T a↑ and T a↓ at P ∼ 1.0 × 10–4 GPa were determined as the maximum of the derivative χT/dT on the χT­(T) curve. The applied pressure was evaluated from the temperature of the transition of high-purity Sn to the superconducting state. For Sn, the T s(P) dependence at pressures below 1.0 GPa is determined by the equation T s(P) = T s(P 0) – aP, where a = 0.365 K GPa–1, and T s(P 0) is the temperature of the transition at atmospheric pressure.The accuracy of pressure calibration was ±0.025 GPa. A correction for the inner decrease in the pressure of liquid or solidified oil cooled from 300 to 6 K, which reaches 0.15–0.20 GPa for the pressure-transmitting medium Daphne 7373 oil, was not applied.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed using an MPMS-2 SQUID magnetometer in the temperature range 6-300 K in a magnetic field of 5 kOe. The temperature dependence of magnetic susceptibility at pressures of 1.0 × 10-4 ⩽ P ⩽ 0.48 GPa was measured in an LPC-15 high-pressure copper-beryllium cell of cylinder-piston type (Japan ElectroLAB) using Daphne 7373 oil as a medium transmitting the hydrostatic pressure, as described elsewhere. The magnetic susceptibility measurements at atmospheric pressure (1.0 × 10-4 GPa) and at a pressure of 0.07-0.78 GPa were performed while cooling/heating the [Cu(hfac)2L]-II samples at a rate of 1 K/min in the temperature range of the magnetic anomaly (ca. T a ± (20-30) K) and at 5 K/min in the other temperature range (settle mode). The experimental data were corrected for the contribution of the high-pressure cell to the total magnetization. In the molar susceptibility calculation, the diamagnetism of atoms was additionally taken into account according to Pascal's additive scheme. The critical temperatures T a↑ and T a↓ at P ~ 1.0 × 10-4 GPa were determined as the maximum of the derivative χT/dT on the χT(T) curve. The applied pressure was evaluated from the temperature of the transition of high-purity Sn to the superconducting state. For Sn, the T s(P) dependence at pressures below 1.0 GPa is determined by the equation T s(P) = T s(P 0) - aP, where a = 0.365 K GPa-1, and T s(P 0) is the temperature of the transition at atmospheric pressure.The accuracy of pressure calibration was ±0.025 GPa. A correction for the inner decrease in the pressure of liquid or solidified oil cooled from 300 to 6 K, which reaches 0.15-0.20 GPa for the pressure-transmitting medium Daphne 7373 oil, was not applied.

elements.content: The intracluster (J, J′) and interchain (J O···O) isotropic exchange parameters were computed by the broken symmetry methodology. The scheme proposed by Yamaguchi and co-workers was employed. These calculations were performed for the {L–Cu­(hfac)2–L} (J, J′) and {L–Cu­(hfac)2–L···L–Cu­(hfac)2–L] (J O···O) fragments using their crystallographically determined geometries within the framework of the UB3LYP/TZVP (Gaussian09 package)­and UB3LYP/def2-TZVP (ORCA 3.0 package) computational procedures.
elements.clean_text: The intracluster (J, J') and interchain (J O⋅⋅⋅O) isotropic exchange parameters were computed by the broken symmetry methodology. The scheme proposed by Yamaguchi and co-workers was employed. These calculations were performed for the {L-Cu(hfac)2-L} (J, J') and {L-Cu(hfac)2-L⋅⋅⋅L-Cu(hfac)2-L] (J O⋅⋅⋅O) fragments using their crystallographically determined geometries within the framework of the UB3LYP/TZVP (Gaussian09 package)and UB3LYP/def2-TZVP (ORCA 3.0 package) computational procedures.

elements.content: The molecular DFT calculations were complemented with band structure calculations. The pseudo potential PW-SCF code of the Quantum Espresso 5.0 package was used for band structure calculations. The ultrasoft pseudo potentials with nonlinear core correction and PBE version of the exchange-correlation potential were used. The kinetic energy cutoffs for wave functions and charge density equal 35 and 280 Ry, respectively. The k space was integrated during self-consistency over the mesh 2 × 2 × 2 in the first Brillouin zone as in the Monkhorst–Pack scheme with displacement of the k-grid at the center of the Brillouin zone and using Gaussian broadening of 0.136 eV. The Hubbard correlations at the Cu and O sites were taken into account within the framework of the GGA+U approximation in Dudarev’s rotationally invariant version with U d(Cu) = 9.8 eV, U p(O) = 5.0 eV.
elements.clean_text: The molecular DFT calculations were complemented with band structure calculations. The pseudo potential PW-SCF code of the Quantum Espresso 5.0 package was used for band structure calculations. The ultrasoft pseudo potentials with nonlinear core correction and PBE version of the exchange-correlation potential were used. The kinetic energy cutoffs for wave functions and charge density equal 35 and 280 Ry, respectively. The k space was integrated during self-consistency over the mesh 2 × 2 × 2 in the first Brillouin zone as in the Monkhorst-Pack scheme with displacement of the k-grid at the center of the Brillouin zone and using Gaussian broadening of 0.136 eV. The Hubbard correlations at the Cu and O sites were taken into account within the framework of the GGA+U approximation in Dudarev's rotationally invariant version with U d(Cu) = 9.8 eV, U p(O) = 5.0 eV.

elements.content: The Q- and W-band CW EPR measurements were performed on commercial Bruker Elexsys E580 and Bruker Elexsys E680 EPR spectrometers, respectively, during the visit of M. V. F. in ETH-Zurich in 2006. The polycrystalline powder was ground and placed in quartz tubes for EPR measurements. For W-band measurements, it was impossible to obtain thin enough powder; therefore, artificial distortions in the spectra were visible at low temperatures because of individual crystallites. They were partly removed by recording the spectra at several sample orientations and summing them up. All simulations used EasySpin software.
elements.clean_text: The Q- and W-band CW EPR measurements were performed on commercial Bruker Elexsys E580 and Bruker Elexsys E680 EPR spectrometers, respectively, during the visit of M. V. F. in ETH-Zurich in 2006. The polycrystalline powder was ground and placed in quartz tubes for EPR measurements. For W-band measurements, it was impossible to obtain thin enough powder; therefore, artificial distortions in the spectra were visible at low temperatures because of individual crystallites. They were partly removed by recording the spectra at several sample orientations and summing them up. All simulations used EasySpin software.

cln_elements.content:
The χT value of [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II (, red circles) at 300 K and atmospheric pressure is 0.89 cm3·K·mol–1, which agrees with the theoretical pure spin value of 0.81 cm3 K mol–1 for two noninteracting spins with S = 1/2 (g R = 2.00, g Cu = 2.15). During the cooling, χT decreases stepwise at ∼140, ∼75, and ∼60 K to the value of 0.40 cm3 K mol–1 characteristic of systems with one unpaired electron for the indicated composition.

An increase in the hydrostatic pressure to 0.07 GPa (, violet diamonds) leads to an unprecedented change in the magnetic properties of the complex: χT decreases to 0.83 cm3·K·mol–1 and remains almost constant in the temperature range 25–300 K; i.e., this relatively small increase in pressure suppresses the three-stage magnetic anomaly observed at atmospheric pressure. When the pressure increases further from 0.07 to 0.78 GPa, χT decreases from 0.83 to 0.51 cm3 K mol–1 already at 300 K, and the dependences χT(T) show a smooth decrease in χT at lower temperatures, reaching ∼0.38 cm3 K mol–1 at T ≈ 100 K, which corresponds to one unpaired electron (S = 1/2).
cln_elements.clean_text:
The χT value of [Cu(hfac)2L]-II (, red circles) at 300 K and atmospheric pressure is 0.89 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1, which agrees with the theoretical pure spin value of 0.81 cm3 K mol-1 for two noninteracting spins with S = 1/2 (g R = 2.00, g Cu = 2.15). During the cooling, χT decreases stepwise at ~140, ~75, and ~60 K to the value of 0.40 cm3 K mol-1 characteristic of systems with one unpaired electron for the indicated composition.

An increase in the hydrostatic pressure to 0.07 GPa (, violet diamonds) leads to an unprecedented change in the magnetic properties of the complex: χT decreases to 0.83 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 and remains almost constant in the temperature range 25-300 K; i.e., this relatively small increase in pressure suppresses the three-stage magnetic anomaly observed at atmospheric pressure. When the pressure increases further from 0.07 to 0.78 GPa, χT decreases from 0.83 to 0.51 cm3 K mol-1 already at 300 K, and the dependences χT(T) show a smooth decrease in χT at lower temperatures, reaching ~0.38 cm3 K mol-1 at T ~ 100 K, which corresponds to one unpaired electron (S = 1/2).

cln_elements.content: Experimental (black circles and line) and calculated χT(T) dependences for [Cu­(hfac)2L]-II. The theoretical points were obtained using the magnetic coupling constants calculated by DFT with neglect of the interchain magnetic coupling J O···O (Table S3): UB3LYP/TZVP (blue squares and dashed line), GGA+U (red triangles).

metadata.title:
Pressure-Controlled Migration of Paramagnetic Centers
in a Heterospin Crystal
